p.s: In the following, Shylock will be characterized in the given scene concentrating on the use of language and stylistic devices.
Throughout the excerpt, Shylock talks much longer than Tubal.
Moreover, he interrupts him (l. 11) and generally leads the conversation by questioning Tubal and in the end also ordering him to get an officer (l. 27).
This portrays him superior to Tubal and shows that Tubal respects Shylock for he does not complain or say anything against Shylock.
Furthermore, Shylock appears very angry about Jessica's eloping which he shows in the parallelism in line 5-7.
There, he says that he wishes her dead at his foot with the things she took from him in her and in her coffin.
He seems very harsh and hateful towards Jessica because he wishes his own daughter nothing but death.
Shylock uses a reversed parallelism The thief ... so much ... so much ... the thief (l. 8).
This also shows his hate for Jessica as he does not call her by her name or my daughter but calls her a thief.

In this, one also sees how he does not count Jessica as a personal loss anymore but instead as a financial loss because she has taken his money and belongings and his search for her costs him a lot as well.
Shylock expresses his hurt and frustration about Jessica eloping with the anaphora no satisfaction, ... of my shedding (ll. 8-10) showing that he feels taht he has lost everything and is very sad.
He does not see an option to make his situation better.

When Tubal tells him about Antonio, Shylock drops out of his grievance of his own situation and with the repetition What, what, what?Ill luck, Ill luck (l. 12) one sees that he is very impatient to hear about Antonio's loss and that this seemingly really moves him.
This manifests in his next repetition in line 14 where he seems very relieved and happy to hear that Antonio has lost his ship due to him thinking god and is so overwhelmed that he cannot believe it.
In line 16, he even calls it good news and this portrays Shylock as very gleeful towards Antonio which also reflects his known hatred for Antonio.

Shylock uses the metaphor thou stickest a dagger in me (l. 18) when talking about Jessica spending lots of money in Genua which, again, shows his deep hurt but also his rage because he compares the physical pain of being stabbed to his pain of having lost money.
This also reflects Shylock seeing his daughter as a financial rather than a personal loss from the beginning of the excerpt and him being mean.

In line 22, Shylock uses the strong parallelism I am very glad of it: I'll plague him, I'll torture him: I am glad of it which makes him seem very harsh because he gleefully talks about Antonio's loss but more than that is revengeseeking for his bond and looking forward to being able to carry out the bond.
His deep hurt about his family also shows itself in his parallelism to Tubal's ... he had of your daughter for a monkey and him saying ... not have given it for a wilderness of monkeys (ll. 23 + 25).
He deeply cares about the ring his wife gave him and is beyond frustrated and hurt that Jessica firstly stole it and then gave it away.
Moreover, in his last expression Shylock comes across very hurried and energetic as he orders Tubal to get an officer because he wants to take revenge on Antonio.
This is created by his repetition of Go, Tubal ... (ll. 27-30) stressing Tubal to quickly fulfill his task.

It also shows Shylock's strategic way of thinking as he sees Antonio's loss as his big chance to take revenge on him and also on his, again, thinking and planning about business whilst playing Antonio's death.
Shylock's cruelness also shows itself in him saying I will have the heart of him, if he forfeit (l. 28).
His bond with Antonio is not that Shylock will kill him or tkae out his heart but just take one pound of flesh but Shylock sees this as a clear opportunity where Antonio will die.
He is very serious about taking revenge on Antonio and feels as if he is, after all, able to carry out his plan.

This manifests in him telling Tubal to get him an officer two weeks before the bond is due (ll. 27f) because he, already in that situation, believes that Antonio will not pay back his debts and therefore forfeit the bonds.
Concludingly, Shylock is shown in two main aspects in this scene: Firstlyfirstly, he is very hurt but at the same time disappointed and angry about Jessica eloping.
He does not see her as a personal loss anymore and just sees his financial loss for which he hates her.
Secondly, Shylock also appears very hateful towards Antonio and is very gleeful about Antonio's loss.
He is strongly demanding revenge from Antonio and feels as if he has defeated him.
In talking about his revenge, Shylock is portrayed very cruel and harsh because wishes Antonio as well as his daughter dead.
